abstract.para: This chapter summarizes frequent problems that can occur while using &productname; and their solutions.

sect1.title: Overview
sect1.para: This chapter is a collection of frequent problems that are reported for &productname;. Additionally, &suse; support collects problems and their solutions online at .

In case of problems, a detailed system report can be created with the supportconfig command line tool. It will collect information about the system such as: current kernel version, hardware, installed packages, partition setup, and much more. The result is a TAR archive of files. After opening a Service Request (SR), you can upload the TAR archive to Global Technical Support. It will help to locate the issue you reported and to assist you in solving the problem. For details, see .

While resolving a technical difficulty with SUSE Support, you may receive a so-called Program Temporary Fix (PTF). PTFs may be issued for various packages as RPMs. For details about handling PTFs, see .
For details about how to contact &suse; support, refer to and .

sect1.title: Debugging Failed Bootstrap
sect1.para: If the bootstrapping as described in fails, there are several places to look for errors. The following procedure outlines where to start debugging.

step.para: Check the logs from Velum dashboard. Execute on the &admin_node;:
Convert the log into a human readable format and open it with less.
Retry bootstrapping from &admin_node; console.
step.screen: &prompt.root.admin;docker exec -it $(docker ps | grep salt-master | awk '{print $1}') \ salt-run -l debug state.orchestrate orch.kubernetes > salt-orchestration.logs

step.para: If the orchestration failed in late state, you can check if etcd and the &kube; cluster is up and running. Log in on a &master_node; and check if etcd cluster is up and running.
step.screen: &prompt.root.master;set -a &prompt.root.master;source /etc/sysconfig/etcdctl &prompt.root.master;etcdctl member list &prompt.root.master;etcdctl endpoint health &prompt.root.master;etcdctl endpoint status &prompt.root.master;journalctl -u etcd
step.para: Check if &kube; cluster is up and running.
step.screen: &prompt.root.master;kubectl get nodes &prompt.root.master;kubectl cluster-info &prompt.root.master;journalctl -u kubelet &prompt.root.master;journalctl -u kube-apiserver &prompt.root.master;journalctl -u kube-scheduler &prompt.root.master;journalctl -u kube-controller-manager

step.para: Collect all relevant logs with supportconfig on the &master_node; and &admin_node;.

sect1.title: Checking etcd Health
sect1.para: To work with etcdctl, you have to pass parameters with paths to required certificates.
Use SSH to log into one of the cluster nodes, for example your first master. The following command provides an example for using etcdctl.

sect1.title: Locking Installed Program Temporary Fixes
sect1.para: It can happen that zypper removes an installed Program Temporary Fix (PTF) when updates are started with Velum. To prevent this, execute the following procedure.

important.title: Locks Disable Updates for Package
important.para: If a package is locked, it will no longer receive any updates until the lock is released with zypper rl.

step.para: Install the PTF manually.
As soon as the node has restarted, verify that the RPM is installed.
Create a zypper lock for this RPM.
Verify that the lock is created.

sect1.title: Using A Proxy Server With Authentication
sect1.para: If you need to register the &admin_node; with &scc; over a proxy server that requires authentication, it is not possible to specify the configuration in /etc/sysconfig/proxy.
For information about setting authentication credentials and connecting to &scc; with SUSEConnect, see .

sect1.title: Replacing TLS/SSL Certificates
sect1.para: Sometimes certificates are not updated properly because they are outdated. To replace outdated certificates, execute the following procedure.

step.para: Use SSH and log in on the &admin_node;.
Move the expired certs out of the way.
Generate new certificates.

tip.title: Generating Additional Certificates
tip.para: To regenerate additional certificates, for example /etc/pki/kubectl-client-cert.crt, add an additional line at the end of the gen-certs.sh script:
tip.screen: &prompt.root.admin;transactional-update shell transactional update # echo "gencert \"kubectl-client-cert\" \"kubectl-client-cert\" \ \"\$all_hostnames\" \"\$(ip_addresses)\"" >>/usr/share/caasp-container-manifests/gen-certs.sh transactional update # /usr/share/caasp-container-manifests/gen-certs.sh transactional update # exit

step.para: Use SSH and log in on a &master_node;.
Backup and delete the dex-tls secret.
step.screen: &prompt.root.master;kubectl -n kube-system get secret dex-tls -o yaml > /root/dex-tls &prompt.root.master;kubectl -n kube-system delete secret dex-tls

step.para: On a master node, find and delete the Dex pods.

important.title: This Step Breaks Authentication
important.para: Executing this step prevents new authentications requests from succeeding. However, the static credentials located on the master nodes will continue to function.
The Dex pods will not restart by themselves until the dex-tls secret is recreated.

step.screen: &prompt.root.master;kubectl -n kube-system get pods | grep dex &prompt.root.master;kubectl -n kube-system delete pods DEX_POD1 DEX_POD2 DEX_POD3

step.para: Manually run the salt orchestration on the &admin_node;. This may take some time.
step.screen: &prompt.root.admin;docker exec -it $(docker ps | grep salt-master | awk '{print $1}') \ bash -c "salt-run state.orchestrate orch.kubernetes" 2&>1 > salt-run.log

step.para: Check the tail of salt-run.log to see if the orchestration succeeded.
On a master node, validate the dex pods are running.
If you are not able to log in into Velum, reboot the &admin_node;. Then test and validate that the cluster is still functional.

sect1.title: Fixing x509: certificate signed by unknown authority
sect1.para: When interacting with &kube; you can run into the situation where your existing configuration for the authentication has changed (cluster has been rebuild, certificates have been switched.)
In such a case you might see an error message in the output of your CLI tool.
sect1.screen: x509: certificate signed by unknown authority
sect1.para: This message indicates that your current system does not know the Certificate Authority (CA) that signed the SSL certificates used for encrypting the communication to the cluster. You then need to add or update the Root CA certificate in your local trust store.
For details about installing the root CA certificate, see .
